questions.text: IV anesthetic agent that causes adrenocortical suppression is: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Etomidate

 

Etomidate causes adrenocortical suppression by inhibiting the 11-beta hydroxylase enzyme in the adrenal cortex. This enzyme is responsible for steroid production in the body. When etomidate inhibits this enzyme, it reduces steroid production, which can lead to adrenocortical suppression. Due to this effect, etomidate should be avoided in critically ill or septic patients where maintaining adequate steroid levels is important for hemodynamic stability.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Propofol: Does not cause adrenocortical suppression. It acts mainly through GABA receptors and affects the central nervous system.

 

Option C. Thiopentone: A barbiturate that acts on GABA receptors but does not affect adrenal function or steroid synthesis.

 

Option D. Ketamine: An NMDA receptor antagonist that actually stimulates the sympathetic system and may increase steroid levels rather than suppress them.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Etomidate causes adrenocortical suppression by inhibiting 11-beta hydroxylase enzyme in the adrenal cortex, making it unsuitable for use in critically ill or septic patients who require normal steroid function.

choices.text: She is susceptible to chicken pox
She is immune to chicken pox

questions.text: A pregnant woman residing in the same house as her niece, who has contracted Varicella, received a negative result in her test for serum antibodies against varicella. What implications can be drawn from this? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) She is susceptible to chicken pox

 

Anti-Varicella/Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV)/Chickenpox IgG; Varicella immunity test

 

  • Negative: Indicates no detectable Varicella IgG antibodies. A negative results indicate no current or previous infection with Varicella virus. Such individuals are presumed to be susceptible to primary infection.
  • Equivocal: Equivocal results are indeterminate. Patient may or may not have immunity to Varicella Virus. It is not acceptable proof of immunity.
  • Positive: Indicates evidence of Varicella IgG antibodies and suggests past or current infection with Varicella virus. Antibodies obtained via acquired immunity or immunization and probable protection from clinical infection. (Immunity).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. She is immune to zoster: Incorrect. Immunity to zoster (shingles) comes from having had a previous varicella (chicken pox) infection or vaccination. A negative antibody test indicates she has not had varicella.

 

Option B. She is susceptible to zoster: Incorrect. Susceptibility to zoster (shingles) typically arises from a reactivation of the varicella virus in individuals who have previously had chicken pox. A negative test means she has not had chicken pox, so she cannot develop zoster but is susceptible to chicken pox.

 

Option D. She is immune to chicken pox: Incorrect. A negative antibody test indicates she does not have immunity to chicken pox.
 

Educational Objective:

 

A negative test result for serum antibodies against varicella indicates that the individual is susceptible to chicken pox, as there are no detectable antibodies suggesting past infection or vaccination.

questions.text: A patient came to the gynecology OPD with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge and intense itching. On examination, the cervix was spotted and had the appearance of a strawberry. Identify the causative organism? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichomonas vaginalis

 

  • Intense vaginal itching and foul-smelling greenish discharge are suggestive of Trichomonas vaginalis infection.
  • Strawberry like appearance of the cervix helps in establishing the diagnosis.
  • On vaginal smear, flagellated organism (T. vaginalis is seen)

 

Other Options:

 

Best understood by this table given below

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichomonas vaginalis infection is characterized by foul-smelling, frothy yellowish-green discharge and a strawberry-like appearance of the cervix.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents to the paediatrician with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). Upon further investigation, a micturating cystourethrogram is performed and which is shown below. The boy is currently asymptomatic and has no history of renal or bladder abnormalities. What could be the cause of the symptoms? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vesicoureteral reflux

 

  • In above case scenario recurrent urinary tract infections and the micturating cystourethrogram showing dilated ureters points towards the diagnosis of vesicoureteral reflux (VUR).
  • Vesicoureteral reflux is a condition where urine flows retrogradely from the bladder back into the ureters and possibly up to the kidneys.
  • VUR is a common cause of recurrent UTIs in children, especially when no other anatomical abnormalities are identified.
  •  The presented imaging findings and clinical history are consistent with VUR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urinary bladder diverticulum: This refers to an outpouching of the bladder wall. It can be congenital or acquired, and these outpouchings can retain urine and be sites of recurrent infections. While bladder diverticula can cause UTIs, the described imaging findings (a dilated ureter) do not align with this diagnosis.

 

 

Option C. Urinary bladder hernia: This is a very rare condition where a portion of the urinary bladder herniates into the surrounding tissue or space. It is not typically associated with the findings described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Varicocele : A varicocele refers to an enlargement of the veins within the scrotum. It is not related to the imaging findings described in the scenario or the symptoms of recurrent UTIs in the patient.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is a common cause of recurrent urinary tract infections in children. The condition is characterized by the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters and potentially up to the kidneys. Imaging findings showing dilated ureters on a micturating cystourethrogram are indicative of VUR.

questions.text: Dermatitis Herpetiformis as a skin manifestation is seen in cases of? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Celiac Sprue

 

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic skin condition characterized by intensely itchy blisters and raised red patches. It is strongly associated with Celiac disease, also known as Celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy. This autoimmune disorder is triggered by the ingestion of gluten, leading to damage in the small intestine and associated skin manifestations like dermatitis herpetiformis. The presence of IgA antibodies against transglutaminase in both the gut and the skin is a key feature linking these conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Options B. Ulcerative Colitis and D. Crohn's disease: This is an inflammatory bowel disease that primarily affects the colon and rectum. It is not associated with dermatitis herpetiformis but can be linked to other skin manifestations like pyoderma gangrenosum and erythema nodosum.

 

  • Erythema Nodosum is characterized by tender red nodules, typically appearing on the shins, and frequently associated with IBD.

 

Option C. Whipple's disease: This is a rare bacterial infection that affects multiple systems in the body, including the gastrointestinal tract. It does not have an association with dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a specific skin manifestation associated with Celiac disease and should prompt the evaluation for gluten sensitivity enteropathy in affected patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of School Health under Ayushman Bharat Program? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Monthly IFA supplementations

 

The Ayushman Bharat Program includes a comprehensive school health component aimed at improving the health and hygiene of school children. The key components include:

 

  • Weekly Iron Folic Acid Supplementation (WIFS): This involves the distribution of iron and folic acid supplements on a weekly basis to prevent anemia among school children. Monthly supplementation is not part of this program; hence, "Monthly IFA supplementations" is the incorrect option.
  • Sanitary Napkins Distribution: Under the menstrual hygiene scheme, sanitary napkins branded as "Freedays" are distributed to adolescent girls to promote menstrual hygiene.
  • Albendazole for Deworming: Deworming through albendazole is conducted to reduce the prevalence of intestinal worm infestations among school-aged children.
  • Health Check-ups: Regular health screenings are conducted to assess the physical and mental fitness of students, ensuring early identification and management of health issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ayushman Bharat School Health Program includes weekly IFA supplementation, not monthly, along with other health initiatives like menstrual hygiene, deworming, screening health check-ups, physical & mental fitness, Research and Vaccination

choices.text: Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is false and reason is also true
Assertion is true and reason is also false

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Myocarditis is the common known complication of faucial diphtheria


Reason (R) : It is due to bacteremia by diphtheria    (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Assertion is true and reason is also false

 

Explanation:

 

Assertion: Myocarditis is indeed a common and serious complication of diphtheria, especially in cases of faucial diphtheria. The diphtheria toxin can cause significant damage to the heart muscle, leading to myocarditis.

 

Reason: The assertion that myocarditis is due to bacteremia by diphtheria is incorrect. Diphtheria does not cause bacteremia. Instead, the complications, including myocarditis, are due to the exotoxin produced by the Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The toxin disseminates through the bloodstream, affecting various organs, including the heart, nerves, and kidneys.

 

  1. Diphtheria Toxin: The pathogenesis of diphtheria involves the production of diphtheria toxin, which is a potent exotoxin. This toxin, rather than the bacteria itself, enters the bloodstream (toxemia) and affects distant organs.
  2. Toxemia vs. Bacteremia: Diphtheria is characterized by toxemia, not bacteremia. The bacteria remain localized at the site of infection (e.g., the throat), but the toxin spreads systemically.
  3. Myocarditis as a Complication: The diphtheria toxin affects the heart muscle, leading to myocarditis, which is the most common and severe complication of diphtheria. Other complications include neuritis and damage to the adrenal glands.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is the correct explanation for the assertion: Incorrect because the reason given is not the correct explanation.

 

Option B. Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion: Incorrect because the reason itself is false.

 

Option C. Assertion is false and reason is also true: Incorrect because the assertion is true, but the reason is false.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myocarditis is a common and serious complication of diphtheria due to the effects of the diphtheria toxin. It is important to recognize that the complications arise from toxemia, not bacteremia.

questions.text: Which agency offers seeds and manure as part of applied nutrition programs in schools? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) UNICEF

 

UNICEF

 

Applied Nutrition Program

 

  • UNICEF promoted the scheme by supplying basic equipment for production and training while FAO and WHO were involved in providing technical advice
  • UNICEF provided seeds, manure and water supply equipment for developing School gardens, to be utilized in school feeding programs

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CARE:  - ‘Cooperative for Assistance and Relief Everywhere’ supports following project:

 

  • Integrated Nutrition and Health Project
  • Better Health and Nutrition Project
  • Anaemia Control Project
  • Improving Women's Health Project
  • Improved Health Care for Adolescent Girl's Project
  • Child Survival Project
  • Improving Women's Reproductive Health and Family Spacing Project
  • Konkan Integrate Development Project

 

Option B. UNDP:  The basic objective of the UNDP is to help poorer nations develop their human and natural resources more fully. The UNDP projects cover virtually every economic and social sector - agriculture, industry, education and science, health, social welfare, etc.

 

Option D. WHO:  World Health Organization aims at the attainment of the highest level of health by all people, which helps them to lead a socially and economically productive life.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

UNICEF provides seeds, manure, and water supply equipment as part of its Applied Nutrition Program to develop school gardens, which are used in school feeding programs to improve children's nutrition.

questions.text: Grievous hurt under Section 320 IPC include all except: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 7 days admission in hospital

 

The duration of hospital stay alone does not define grievous hurt under IPC 320. The nature and severity of the injury are the determining factors, not the length of hospitalization.

 

Other Options:

 

Grievous hurt under Section 320 IPC:

 

Option A. Permanent privation of hearing: This is considered grievous hurt as it results in the permanent loss of a sense, causing significant and lasting disability.

 

Option B. Fracture femur: Fracture of the femur is explicitly mentioned under IPC 320 as grievous hurt due to the severity and potential long-term consequences of the injury.

 

Option D. Emasculation: This involves depriving a man of his masculine vigour and is considered grievous hurt due to the significant physical and psychological impact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Grievous hurt under IPC 320 involves injuries that cause permanent disability, severe bodily pain, or life-altering effects. Hospital stay duration alone does not qualify an injury as grievous hurt unless accompanied by a severe or specified injury under the law.

questions.text: Name the hormone secreted by the marked cell: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcitonin

 

The marked cells in the histology image are parafollicular cells, also known as C cells, located in the thyroid gland. These cells are found outside the thyroid follicles, which are filled with colloid. Parafollicular cells are responsible for secreting the hormone calcitonin.

 

Calcitonin plays a crucial role in calcium homeostasis by lowering blood calcium levels when they are too high. It achieves this by inhibiting osteoclast activity in bones, which decreases the release of calcium into the bloodstream.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adrenaline: Adrenaline is secreted by the adrenal medulla, not by the cells in the thyroid gland. Therefore, it is not related to the marked cells in the image.

 

Option C. Prolactin: Prolactin is produced by the anterior pituitary gland and is involved in milk production in the mammary glands. It is not secreted by the thyroid gland or its parafollicular cells.

 

Option D. Thyroxine: Thyroxine (T4) is secreted by the follicular cells of the thyroid gland, not the parafollicular cells. The marked cells in the image are outside the follicles and are responsible for calcitonin secretion, not thyroxine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The parafollicular cells (C cells) in the thyroid gland secrete calcitonin, a hormone that helps regulate calcium levels in the blood.

questions.text: Most important enzyme in acute inflammation during respiratory burst is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) NADPH oxidase

 

The respiratory burst is a crucial process in the immune response where neutrophils rapidly increase their oxygen consumption to generate reactive oxygen species (ROS) to kill invading pathogens. The key enzyme that initiates this process is NADPH oxidase (aka Respiratory burst oxidase enzyme). NADPH oxidase catalyzes the conversion of oxygen (O₂) into superoxide anions (O₂⁻), which are then further converted into more reactive species like hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) and hypochlorous acid (HOCl-) via other enzymes like myeloperoxidase (MPO). These reactive species are potent antimicrobial agents, essential for destroying bacteria and fungi during acute inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MPO (Myeloperoxidase): While MPO is important in the conversion of hydrogen peroxide into hypochlorous acid (a powerful microbicidal agent), it acts downstream of NADPH oxidase. Thus, it is not the primary enzyme initiating the respiratory burst.

 

Option C. Defensin: Defensins are antimicrobial peptides that kill bacteria particularly against mycobacterium tuberculosis, by disrupting their cell membranes. They do not play a direct role in the respiratory burst or the generation of ROS.

 

Option D. Catalase: Catalase is an enzyme that breaks down hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen, acting as an antioxidant to protect cells from oxidative damage. It does not contribute to the generation of ROS in the respiratory burst and is involved in mitigating the effects of ROS rather than promoting their formation.

 

Also, Catalase activity is used as a diagnostic tool to differentiate between types of bacteria. For example, the presence of catalase is used to distinguish catalase-positive organisms like Staphylococcus (staph) from catalase-negative organisms like Streptococcus (strep).

 

Educational Objective:

 

NADPH oxidase is the most important enzyme in the process of respiratory burst during acute inflammation. It initiates the production of reactive oxygen species, which are crucial for the immune system's ability to kill pathogens.

questions.text: In which condition is excessive urinary excretion of 5- hydroxy indole acetic acid (5HIAA) seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carcinoid syndrome

 

Carcinoid syndrome is the correct answer. It is a condition associated with the overproduction of serotonin by certain tumors, known as carcinoid tumors. Elevated serotonin levels can lead to increased 5HIAA excretion in the urine. This condition is known for causing flushing, diarrhea, and other symptoms.

 

5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5HIAA) is a metabolite of serotonin, a neurotransmitter that is produced in the enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal tract. In normal circumstances, most of the serotonin produced in the enterochromaffin cells is metabolized in the liver and then excreted in the urine as 5HIAA. However, in carcinoid syndrome, serotonin-secreting tumors can produce excessive amounts of serotonin that overwhelm the metabolic capacity of the liver, resulting in high levels of urinary 5HIAA.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alkaptonuria is a rare genetic disorder in which homogentisic acid is not properly metabolized, leading to its accumulation in various tissues and the urine. This condition is not related to serotonin metabolism.

 

Option B. Albinism is a genetic disorder that results in reduced or absent production of melanin, the pigment that gives color to the skin, hair, and eyes. This condition is also not related to serotonin metabolism.

 

Option D. Phenylketonuria is an inherited metabolic disorder in which the body cannot properly process the amino acid phenylalanine. This results in the accumulation of toxic byproducts that can lead to intellectual disability, seizures, and other serious health problems. This condition is also not related to serotonin metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carcinoid syndrome leads to the overproduction of serotonin by carcinoid tumors, resulting in increased levels of its metabolite, 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5HIAA), in the urine, which is a diagnostic marker for this syndrome.

questions.text: A person fell in the dark while climbing stairs and sustained an injury to the posterior triangle of the neck from an iron nail. Afterwards, he experienced difficulty in raising his shoulder and was unable to shrug. Which structure is most likely to be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Accessory nerve

 

The accessory nerve, also known as the 11th cranial nerve, innervates the trapezius muscle. The trapezius muscle is responsible for movements such as shrugging the shoulders. An injury to the posterior triangle of the neck could damage the accessory nerve, leading to weakness in the trapezius muscle. This would manifest as difficulty in raising the shoulder and an inability to shrug, as described in the scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Long thoracic nerve: This nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which is involved in the movement of the scapula, not shrugging of the shoulder. Damage to this nerve typically leads to a condition known as "winged scapula," not an inability to shrug.

 

Option B. Deltoid muscle: The deltoid muscle is responsible for the abduction of the arm, particularly the movement of the arm away from the body. While it plays a role in shoulder movement, it is not involved in shrugging the shoulder.

 

Option D. Sternocleidomastoid muscle: This muscle is involved in turning the chin to the opposite side and flexing the neck. It is not responsible for shoulder elevation or shrugging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The accessory nerve is crucial for the function of the trapezius muscle, which enables the shrugging of the shoulder. An injury to this nerve can result in the inability to perform this action.

choices.text: 200-400 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours.
400-700 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours.
700-900 ml of ORS to be given in the first 4 hours.
In addition to the usual fluid intake, 100-200 ml should be given after each loose stool.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a 9-month-old baby with diarrhea, who is feeding adequately, thirsty, and exhibits skin that returns to normal after a pinch within 2 seconds? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 400-700 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours. 

 

  • According to the IMNCI classification, the baby has some dehydration and comes under Plan B. The amount of ORS given is 75ml/kg body weight.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a 9-month-old baby showing signs of some dehydration due to diarrhea, it is crucial to administer 400-700 ml of ORS over the first four hours, adhering to IMNCI guidelines. This approach ensures effective initial rehydration and sets the stage for ongoing recovery and feeding.

questions.text: Identify the structure given in the image: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incus

 

The structure given in the image is the incus.

 

The malleus has head, neck, handle (manubrium), a lateral and an anterior process. Head and neck of malleus lie in the attic. Manubrium is embedded in the fibrous layer of the tympanic membrane. The lateral process forms a knob-like projection on the outer surface of the tympanic membrane and gives attachment to the anterior and posterior malleolar folds.

 

The incus has a body and a short process, both of which lie in the attic, and a long process which hangs vertically and attaches to the head of stapes.

 

The stapes has a head, neck, anterior and posterior crura, and a footplate. The footplate is held in the oval window by annular ligament.


Other Options:

 

Option A. The malleus is the largest ossicle and is shaped like a mallet. The parts of the malleus are the head, neck, handle (manubrium), and anterior and lateral processes. The head and neck lie in the attic.

 

The tympanic membrane is connected to the handle of the malleus.

 

Option C. The stapes has a head, neck, footplate, and anterior and posterior crura. The annular ligament holds the footplate of stapes in the oval window.

 

 

The joints between the ear ossicles are synovial joints. A saddle-shaped joint is present between the incus and malleus. Incus and stapes articulate via a ball and socket joint.

 

Options D. Vomer A facial bone forming part of the nasal septum, unrelated to the middle ear.

Educational Objective:

 

The incus is one of the three auditory ossicles in the middle ear. It plays a critical role in hearing by transmitting sound vibrations from the malleus to the stapes.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 9

choices.text: Increase in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure
Decrease in glomerular capillary oncotic pressure
Increase in renal plasma flow
Increase in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.text: Which of the following decreases GFR? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

 

Explanation:

 

Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) is determined by the balance of pressures acting on the glomerulus. The key pressures involved are the glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure, which drives filtration, and the oncotic pressure, which opposes it. Additionally, the hydrostatic pressure within Bowman's capsule also opposes filtration.

 

Increase in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure: This is the back pressure exerted by the fluid already in Bowman's capsule. If this pressure increases, it opposes the hydrostatic pressure of the glomerular capillaries, leading to a decrease in GFR. For example, conditions such as ureteric obstruction can increase this pressure, resulting in reduced GFR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure: This pressure pushes fluid out of the capillaries and into Bowman's capsule, thus increasing GFR. Therefore, increasing this pressure would not decrease GFR.

 

Option B. Decrease in glomerular capillary oncotic pressure: Oncotic pressure is the "holding" pressure due to plasma proteins. A decrease in this pressure would result in less opposition to filtration, thereby increasing GFR, not decreasing it.

 

Option C. Increase in renal plasma flow: An increase in renal plasma flow generally leads to an increase in GFR because more plasma is being filtered through the kidneys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An increase in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure decreases GFR

questions.text: Which of the following antiretroviral drugs is not used in HIV & hepatitis B co-infection? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Abacavir

 

HLA B 57:01 mutation is associated with hypersensitivity to abacavir.

 

Abacavir is used in PLHIV with renal failure however is not effective against HBV.

 

Other options:

 

Option A, C, D inhibit both HIV reverse transcriptase and HBV DNA polymerase, thereby, inhibiting their replication.

 

M184V mutation results in resistance to Lamivudine, emtricitabine. However, increases susceptibility to tenofovir, zidovudine and also reduces rate of viral replication (Beneficial). Hence addition of boosted protease inhibitor + lamivudine is continued in such cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the treatment of patients with HIV and hepatitis B co-infection, abacavir is not used due to its lack of efficacy against HBV. Instead, drugs like tenofovir, lamivudine, and emtricitabine, which have dual activity against both viruses, are preferred.

 

Reference: NACO 2021 HIV Care and treatment guidelines

questions.text: Resistance to which of the following antitubercular drugs occurs due to mutation in kat G? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Isoniazid

 

Explanation

 

  • Isoniazid (INH) is a prodrug which activated by catalase peroxidase (formed by Kat G) enzyme of mycobacteria. It acts by inhibiting the formation of mycolic acid.
  • Mutation in Kat G or inh A can result in resistance.
  • When there is a mutation in the katG gene, the catalase-peroxidase enzyme is either not produced or is produced in a dysfunctional form. As a result, isoniazid cannot be activated and can’t inhibit the formation of mycolic acid. This leads to resistance to isoniazid.
  • The katG gene mutation is one of the most common mechanisms of isoniazid resistance in M. tuberculosis. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rifampicin: Incorrect. Rifampicin resistance is primarily associated with mutations in the rpo B gene, which encodes the β-subunit of RNA polymerase. Rifampicin acts by binding to this β-subunit, inhibiting transcription. When mutations occur in the rpoB gene, rifampicin cannot bind effectively, leading to resistance.

 

Option C. Levofloxacin: Incorrect. Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that targets DNA gyrase (topoisomerase II) and topoisomerase IV in bacteria. Resistance to levofloxacin typically occurs due to mutations in gyr A or gyr B genes, which encode DNA gyrase.

 

Option D. Pyrazinamide: Incorrect. Pyrazinamide resistance is mainly associated with mutations in the pncA gene, which encodes pyrazinamidase. This enzyme converts pyrazinamide to its active form, pyrazinoic acid. Mutations in pncA result in reduced pyrazinamidase activity, leading to pyrazinamide resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Resistance to isoniazid occurs due to mutations in the katG gene, which encodes the catalase-peroxidase enzyme required for isoniazid activation.

choices.text: Red degeneration of fibroid
Torsion of fibroid
None of the above

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a fibroid uterus develops severe acute pain abdomen at 28 weeks of gestation. There is no history of fever. WBC count is 8000cells/µl. The most likely diagnosis is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red degeneration of fibroid 

 

Explanation:

 

Red degeneration- occurs mostly in pregnancy. Due to thrombosis of capsular veins.

 

  • Patient presents with tense, tender abdomen with fever.
  • After excluding other obstetric complications (e.g.- abruption, appendicitis, twisted ovarian cyst, pyelitis)
  • Treatment:  Symptomatic - hydration, rest and analgesia
  • Surgical management AVOIDED

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pre-term labor: This is unlikely, as in preterm labor, the pain isn’t acute severe. It will be increasing in intensity and frequency and occurring at regular intervals. Preterm labor is also associated with cervical dilatation and effacement

 

Option C. Torsion of Fibroid: This can happen in a pedunculated subserous fibroid but is quite a rare occurrence, It will be additionally associated with vomiting and will require surgical management

 

Educational Objective:

 

Red degeneration of fibroid during pregnancy presents with acute severe pain, and symptomatic treatment is the primary approach, avoiding surgical intervention.

 

Ref: Page no 275, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gyn 6th edition

questions.text: Congenital lactic acidosis is due to the defect of: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pyruvate dehydrogenase

 

Congenital lactic acidosis occurs when there is an accumulation of lactic acid in the body from birth, often due to a metabolic defect. In normal metabolism, glucose is converted to pyruvate through glycolysis. Under aerobic conditions, pyruvate is transported into the mitochondria, where it is converted into acetyl-CoA by the enzyme pyruvate dehydrogenase. Acetyl-CoA then enters the Krebs cycle to produce energy in the form of ATP.

 

When there is a deficiency or defect in the pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme, pyruvate cannot be converted to acetyl-CoA. As a result, pyruvate accumulates and is instead converted to lactate, leading to lactic acidosis. Since this condition is present from birth, it is termed congenital lactic acidosis. Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency is one of the key causes of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transketolase: This enzyme plays a role in the pentose phosphate pathway (also known as the hexose monophosphate shunt) and is not directly involved in the conversion of pyruvate or the production of lactic acid. Defects in transketolase do not lead to congenital lactic acidosis.

 

Option B. Branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase: This enzyme is involved in the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids and its deficiency causes Maple Syrup Urine Disease, not congenital lactic acidosis. It is unrelated to pyruvate metabolism.

 

Option C. Isocitrate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is part of the Krebs cycle, catalyzing the conversion of isocitrate to alpha-ketoglutarate. While it is involved in cellular respiration, defects in this enzyme are not responsible for congenital lactic acidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency is a key cause of congenital lactic acidosis, as it prevents the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, leading to an accumulation of lactic acid.

questions.text: Match the following blood components with their shelf life:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b

 

Explanation:

 

The shelf life of blood components varies depending on their storage conditions and preservation methods. Here's a detailed explanation of the correct matches:

 

  1. Single donor platelets: Shelf life is 5 days when stored with continuous agitation to prevent clumping. This is essential to maintain the efficacy and viability of the platelets.
  2. Packed RBC: Shelf life is 42 days when stored in a preservative solution containing saline, adenine, glucose, and mannitol (SAGM). This extends the shelf life while maintaining the quality of the red blood cells.
  3. Cryoprecipitate: Shelf life is 1 year when stored at temperatures below -18°C. Cryoprecipitate is used for patients with clotting factor deficiencies, such as hemophilia A and von Willebrand disease.
  4. Granulocytes concentrate: Shelf life is 24 hours. This component contains white blood cells and is used for patients with severe neutropenia, such as those with febrile neutropenia or aplastic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Single donor platelets have a shelf life of 5 days, packed RBCs 42 days, cryoprecipitate 1 year, and granulocytes concentrate 24 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for reversing the effect of muscle relaxation/anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neostigmine

 

Neostigmine is primarily used to reverse the effects of non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents used during surgery to induce muscle relaxation.

 

Neostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, meaning it inhibits the enzyme acetylcholinesterase, which normally breaks down acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. By inhibiting this enzyme, neostigmine increases the concentration of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. The excess acetylcholine competes with and displaces the non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers (e.g., rocuronium) from the acetylcholine receptors. As a result, acetylcholine can again bind to the receptors, leading to muscle depolarization and contraction, effectively reversing the muscle relaxation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Succinylcholine: Incorrect because succinylcholine is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker itself and is used to induce muscle relaxation rather than reverse it. It is not used for reversing muscle relaxation.

 

Option C. Glycopyrrolate: Incorrect because glycopyrrolate is an anticholinergic agent used to counteract the side effects of neostigmine, such as bradycardia and bronchospasm. While it is often administered alongside neostigmine, it is not responsible for reversing muscle relaxation.

 

Option D. Atropine: Incorrect because atropine is another anticholinergic agent used to mitigate the side effects of neostigmine, similar to glycopyrrolate. It does not reverse muscle relaxation but helps prevent bradycardia and other cholinergic side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neostigmine is the primary drug used to reverse the effects of non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents, by increasing acetylcholine levels at the neuromuscular junction and allowing muscle contraction to resume.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles are supplied by the lateral plantar nerve? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Abductor hallucis
  2. Flexor digitorum accessorius
  3. Flexor hallucis brevis
  4. First lumbrical
  5. First interossei
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 5

 

 

 

The lateral plantar nerve is a branch of the tibial nerve, which innervates various muscles in the sole of the foot. It divides into superficial and deep branches, each supplying specific muscles.

 

  • Flexor Digitorum Accessorius : This muscle assists in the flexion of the toes and is supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.
  • First Interossei: The interossei muscles, which include the dorsal and plantar interossei, are responsible for abduction and adduction of the toes. The first interossei is supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Abductor hallucis: This muscle is supplied by the medial plantar nerve, not the lateral plantar nerve.

 

3. Flexor hallucis brevis: This muscle is also supplied by the medial plantar nerve.

 

4. First lumbrical: The first lumbrical is supplied by the medial plantar nerve, whereas the second, third, and fourth lumbricals are supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral plantar nerve supplies the flexor digitorum accessorius (quadratus plantae) and the first interossei muscles in the foot.

questions.text: Following images show the sample collected from a patient complaining of perianal itching. The diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enterobius vermicularis

 

Enterobius vermicularis, commonly known as pinworm, is the most common cause of perianal itching, especially in children. This worm lays its eggs around the perianal region, which leads to intense itching. The characteristic D-shaped (plano-convex) eggs seen in the images further confirm the diagnosis of Enterobius vermicularis. The images depict the typical appearance of the worm’s head and its eggs, which have a clear, thick shell with one flattened side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma: Ancylostoma, also known as hookworm, typically causes symptoms like iron deficiency anemia due to blood loss from the intestines. It does not typically cause perianal itching, and its eggs are not D-shaped.

 

Option C. H Nana: Hymenolepis nana, the dwarf tapeworm, causes hymenolepiasis, which can present with gastrointestinal symptoms but not specifically perianal itching. Its eggs are spherical with polar filaments, which are distinctly different from the D-shaped eggs of Enterobius vermicularis.

 

Option D. Necator americanus: This is another type of hookworm that primarily causes symptoms related to iron deficiency anemia and gastrointestinal discomfort. It does not typically cause perianal itching, and its eggs are oval with a thin, smooth shell, different from those of Enterobius vermicularis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterobius vermicularis is associated with perianal itching and produces characteristic D-shaped eggs.

choices.text: Opening of calcium channels

questions.text: According to myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation, the afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch-induced by? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Opening of calcium channels

 

Explanation

 

Renal autoregulation is important to maintain the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Blood flow to kidneys remains normal even when the mean arterial blood pressure varies widely between 60 mm Hg and 180 mm Hg. This helps to maintain normal GFR.

 

Two mechanisms are involved in renal autoregulation:

 

  1. Myogenic response
  2. Tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF)

 

1. MYOGENIC RESPONSE

 

Whenever, the blood flow to kidneys increases,  →  stretches the elastic wall of the afferent arteriole →  Stretching of the vessel wall increases the flow of calcium ions from extracellular fluid into the cells →  The influx of calcium ions leads to the contraction of smooth muscles in afferent arteriole, which causes constriction of afferent arteriole →  So, the blood flow is decreased.

 

 

2. TGF

 

The macula densa, a plaque of specialized tubular epithelial cells located in the distal tubule, monitors the NaCl concentration of the tubular fluid and sends an as of yet unidentified signal to control glomerular hemodynamics. In this mechanism, called tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF), an increase in NaCl concentration at the macula densa constricts the glomerular afferent arteriole and thus decreases the single-nephron GFR. Along with the myogenic response, TGF significantly contributes to renal autoregulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NO: Incorrect, as nitric oxide generally causes vasodilation, not the contraction associated with the myogenic response.

 

Option B. Noradrenaline: Incorrect, although noradrenaline can affect blood vessel tone, it is not directly involved in the myogenic response mechanism of renal autoregulation.

 

Option D. Adenosine: Incorrect, adenosine is more involved in tubuloglomerular feedback rather than the myogenic mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In renal autoregulation, the myogenic hypothesis states that the afferent arterioles contract in response to increased blood pressure, which stretches the arteriole walls. This contraction is mediated by the opening of calcium channels, leading to an influx of calcium ions and subsequent constriction of the arteriole, thereby helping to stabilize GFR across varying blood pressures.
